module.title: iarr
module.p: iarr is a (regular) verb with the basic meaning of ask for, request. When used in the progressive it often has the extended volitional meaning want, desire.
When used non-progressively (i.e. in a perfective clause), iarr generally carries the meaning ask somebody for or to do something.

ol.li: Simple transitive – iarr rud ask for something, e.g. dh’iarr mi cù I asked for a dog
Extended transitive – iarr rud air duine ask somebody for something, e.g. dh’iarr mi cù air Màiri I asked Mary for a dog
Cas mu seach – iarr rud a dhèanamh ask to do something, e.g. dh’iarr mi an cù a bhiathadh I asked to feed the dog
Extended cas mu seach – iarr air duine rud a dhèanamh ask somebody to do something, e.g. dh’iarr mi air Màiri an cù a bhiathadh I asked Mary to feed the dog
Object clause – iarr nach ask that ... not, e.g. dh’iarr mi nach biathadh Màiri an cù I asked that Mary not feed the dog

box.title: Simple transitive use of iarr
box.p: When used as a simple transitive verb, iarr usually has the meaning ask for something –
When used with a verb of motion and intention, this basic meaning is often generalised to (come/go and) fetch/collect something –

box.title: iarr rud air duine
box.p: When used transitively with an air prepositional phrase, iarr rud air duine means ask somebody for something –

box.title: iarr rud a dhèanamh
box.p: When used with a cas mu seach construction (object inversion), iarr rud a dhèanamh means ask to do something –

box.title: iarr air duine rud a dhèanamh
box.p: When used with a cas mu seach construction and an air prepositional phrase, iarr air duine rud a dhèanamh means ask somebody to do something –
